Suppose the organism is diploid, and the fitness of the dominant allele is 1 + s, and the recessive is 1 - s. The mean fitness of the population would be (p^2)(1 - s) + (2pq)(1 + s) + (q^2)(1 + s). But since p is very small, q≈1, so mean fitness ≈ (0)(1 - s) + (2p)(1 + s) + (1)(1 + s) ≈ 2p(1 + s) + (1 + s) = (1 + s)(2p + 1). The equilibrium mutation rate is when the change in allele frequency Δp ≈ (μ - μ'p)/(W̄), where W̄ is the mean fitness. Setting Δp=0 gives μ = μ'p. Here, μ' is the mutation rate from the recessive allele, but since p is negligible, μ ≈ μ' * p. The mutation rate from the recessive allele is μ'' = (s * q)/2 ≈ s/2. So, equating μ ≈ μ'' * p, we get μ ≈ (s/2) * p. Substituting s=0.6 and p=1/8000: μ ≈ (0.6/2) * (1/8000) = 0.3 * 1.25e-4 ≈ 3.75e-5. Closest to option C (3e-5). A. 2.5 × 10^-5

B. 1.5 × 10^-5

C. 3.0 × 10^-5

D. 4.0 × 10^-5

E. 5.0 × 10^-5

F. 1.0 × 10^-5

G. 1.2 × 10^-5

H. 2.0 × 10^-5

I. 6.0 × 10^-5

J. 3.5 × 10^-5

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
